text:
*[Bug 15941] Long, multiple-expression console input causes premature EOF*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=15941>

Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
                 CC|                            |tomas.kalibera@gmail.com
         Resolution|---                         |FIXED
             Status|REOPENED                    |CLOSED

--- Comment #3 from Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) ---
Thanks for the report and initial analysis, fixed in R-devel.

Yes, the problem is between the repl and the parser - the interaction between
the two is rather complicated due to the iterative mechanism of parsing using a
partial view of the input. This particular case was caused by the parser seeing
just a space, which it would signal as end of file and the repl would stop. The
parser tries to indicate in some cases that the input may be incomplete (such
as when it ends inside a token, etc), but it really cannot know when it doesn't
see until the end of the input. This is now fixed in R-devel in the repl - it
would keep trying longer inputs even when the parser reports EOF.

Whenever one has a choice, say when generating code, as hardly one would
hand-write such long lines - it is better to use short lines, certainly shorter
than 4K. That avoids this complicated iterative mechanism, which doesn't get
much tested (as such long lines are rare).

*[Bug 16212] Invisible character in script file but shows in console when run*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=16212>

Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
             Status|NEW                         |CLOSED
                 CC|                            |tomas.kalibera@gmail.com
         Resolution|---                         |NOT REPRODUCIBLE

--- Comment #1 from Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) ---
Thanks for the report. Unfortunately we cannot debug this (or even fix it, if
it is a bug in R) when even you were not able to reproduce it. Rgui uses a
low-level interface to read the keyboard input, and it is certainly not
impossible it got confused somehow if the input is happening in a different way
with your keyboard, it may also be an interaction between what Windows does
with such input and what Rgui expects.

Initially I wanted to speculate this may have been caused by a multi-byte
character that was not visible in the script text, but I wasn't able to provoke
a similar thing using such character. Certainly Rgui input handling has been
significantly updated since this report (also to handle more characters, to fix
various bugs). Also since R 4.2, UTF-8 is the native encoding, which required
some changes even in Rgui.

If you run into anything like this again and can reproduce at least on your
system, please report.

<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=16855>

Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
             Status|UNCONFIRMED                 |CLOSED
         Resolution|---                         |WONTFIX
                 CC|                            |tomas.kalibera@gmail.com

--- Comment #1 from Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) ---
R on Windows doesn't support Cygwin (see also the R Installation and
Administration manual). We don't have the resources to do that, instead we
target mingw-w64. There would certainly be many problems to fix, if R were to
work on Cygwin, than this one.

Rtools use Cygwin via Msys2, but this is solely for the build tools to build R
natively on Windows, using mingw-w64.

<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=15942>

Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
             Status|NEW                         |CLOSED
         Resolution|---                         |NOT REPRODUCIBLE
                 CC|                            |tomas.kalibera@gmail.com

--- Comment #2 from Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) ---
Unfortunately I can't reproduce the problem. If there was some check in base R,
executed within "R CMD check" or "R CMD check --as-cran", which relied on
writable DESCRIPTION file in the library, that would be strange and worth
looking at, and ideal would be a report that would point to the specific piece
of code. Or a much "smaller" and reproducible example.

In the normal use of R, when R is installed via the CRAN installer to the
default location (C:\Program Files), it will also be read-only to regular
users, including the DESCRIPTION file of the recommended packages.

I tried R CMD check (and --as-cran) on lattice, which uses grid, and it worked
fine.

Then, looking at your example package (mass.zip). I had to unpack it and place
it in a directory named fakepackage (to match the DESCRIPTION) for the
experiment. R CMD INSTALL and check (and --as-cran) worked fine.

The output in the report suggests that the installation (ran as a part of
checking) of the package failed, but not, why. If it tried to modify some
read-only file, it should be possible to see that in some output (or confirm
that via say process monitor).

*[Bug 16927] large mismatched data.frame creation provokes a crash*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=16927>

Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
         Resolution|---                         |NOT REPRODUCIBLE
                 CC|                            |tomas.kalibera@gmail.com
             Status|UNCONFIRMED                 |CLOSED

--- Comment #1 from Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) ---
Thanks for the report. I can reproduce the crash on a Windows server with 192G
of RAM with R 3.3.0. However, it does not crash in R-devel (to become R 4.6.0),
one gets that expected R error (as on Linux).

I would optimistically assume the underlying cause of the problem has been
removed in the meantime - a potentially related change was that R on Windows
now uses the system memory allocator (and consequently support for the heap
memory limit on Windows has been removed). Trying to debug the 9 years old
version of R at this point wouldn't be worth the effort, but if you run into a
similar crash in current R, please report.

<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=16674>

Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
                 CC|                            |tomas.kalibera@gmail.com
         Resolution|---                         |NOT REPRODUCIBLE
             Status|UNCONFIRMED                 |CLOSED

--- Comment #1 from Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) ---
I can reproduce the problem in R 3.2.3, but not in the current R-devel.
Hopefully this means the problem has been fixed in the meantime; debugging that
old version of R at this point probably wouldn't be worth the effort.

In R 3.2.3, NULL is also returned (after running the initial code from the
report) by La_version(), which could mean that the lapack module wasn't loaded
properly. However, there are checks in place for that, one should see a warning
when the module cannot be loaded, and then one should get an error when calling
a LAPACK function (already in 3.2.3). Interestingly, deleting the objects and
then running gc() several times to clean up the memory doesn't help - LAPACK
routines still return NULL.

*[Bug 18358] Output from cluster workers is not printed to console when outfile = ""*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18358>

Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
                 CC|                            |tomas.kalibera@gmail.com
         Resolution|---                         |Works as documented
             Status|UNCONFIRMED                 |CLOSED

--- Comment #1 from Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) ---
Unfortunately, it is not possible to show output from asynchronously running
processes, as they progress, on the Rgui console in Windows. The cluster
workers are ran using system(wait=FALSE), for which this is documented, but
I've now documented it also for makeCluster().

I would use a file for this purpose via the "outfile" argument, and if it
needed to be monitored on the fly when the workers are still running, I would
monitor it from a different process. If this is just for easy debugging, one
could also use some Windows console application for that and run Rterm in it,
but I would simply use the file, and even on Unix from the terminal - to have
the worker messages isolated from the rest.
